definition:
Let $G$ be a graph. A *matching* $M$ on $G$ is a subset of the edges of
$G$ such that each vertex in $G$ is incident with no more than one edge
in $M$.

It is easy to find a matching on a graph; for example, the empty set
will always be a matching. Typically, the most interesting matchings are
*maximal matchings*. A maximal matching on a graph $G$ is simply a
matching of the largest possible size.

A *perfect matching* is a matching that saturates every vertex.
